dotPoints: Calculations involving equilibrium expressions (including units) for a closed homogeneous equilibrium system and the dependence of the equilibrium constant (K) value on the system temperature and the equation used to represent the reaction

equilibrium_expression_structure.name: Equilibrium Expression Structure
equilibrium_expression_structure.correct: The equilibrium expression has products in the numerator and reactants in the denominator, each raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients.

reactants over products.fix: Products always go on TOP (numerator), reactants on BOTTOM (denominator).
reactants over products.action: Memory aid: K favours products when large, so products are on top.

products minus reactants.fix: The equilibrium expression is a RATIO of concentrations, not a difference.
products minus reactants.action: Write out K = [C][D]/[A][B] for A + B ⇌ C + D. No minus signs.

products plus reactants.fix: Equilibrium expressions divide product concentrations BY reactant concentrations.

products times reactants.error: K is a ratio, not a product of all concentrations.
products times reactants.fix: Products and reactants are separated by a division bar, not multiplied together.
products times reactants.action: Review: K tells us the ratio of products to reactants at equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the structure of equilibrium expressions.
persistent.action: Write 5 different equilibrium expressions from balanced equations. Products always on top.

stoichiometric_coefficients.name: Role of Stoichiometric Coefficients
stoichiometric_coefficients.correct: Stoichiometric coefficients from the balanced equation become powers (exponents) in the equilibrium expression.

multiplied by concentration.action: For 2NO₂ ⇌ N₂O₄: K = [N₂O₄]/[NO₂]². The 2 is a power, not a multiplier.

added to concentration.error: Coefficients are raised as powers, not added.
added to concentration.fix: The coefficient becomes an exponent on the concentration.
added to concentration.action: Practice: write K for N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃. What powers do you get?

ignored in the expression.error: Coefficients are essential to the equilibrium expression.
ignored in the expression.fix: Every coefficient becomes a power in the K expression.
ignored in the expression.action: Compare K for H₂ + I₂ ⇌ 2HI vs H₂ + I₂ ⇌ HI. They're different.

only affect products.error: Coefficients apply to both products AND reactants.
only affect products.fix: All species have their coefficients converted to powers.
only affect products.action: Write K for 2SO₂ + O₂ ⇌ 2SO₃. Both sides have powers.

persistent.gap: You're confusing coefficients in equations with powers in expressions.
persistent.action: Rule: coefficient → power. Practice with 5 equations until automatic.

k_value_meaning.name: Meaning of K Values
k_value_meaning.correct: A large K (much greater than 1) means products are favoured at equilibrium. A small K (much less than 1) means reactants are favoured.

K > 1 favours reactants.fix: Large K = more products. Products are in the numerator, so large K means large [products].
K > 1 favours reactants.action: Think: K = [products]/[reactants]. Big K = big numerator = lots of products.

K determines reaction rate.fix: K tells you WHERE equilibrium lies, not HOW FAST you get there.
K determines reaction rate.action: Rate depends on k (rate constant). Position depends on K (equilibrium constant).

K = 1 means no reaction.error: K = 1 means equal amounts of products and reactants.
K = 1 means no reaction.fix: At K = 1, neither products nor reactants are favoured.
K = 1 means no reaction.action: Calculate: if [products] = [reactants], what is K? It's 1.

K shows yield percentage.error: K is a ratio, not a percentage.
K shows yield percentage.fix: K compares products to reactants but isn't directly a yield.
K shows yield percentage.action: K = 100 doesn't mean 100% yield. It means products are 100× more concentrated than reactants (adjusted for stoichiometry).

persistent.gap: You don't understand what K values represent.
persistent.action: Key: K = [products]/[reactants]. Large K = products favoured. Small K = reactants favoured. Practice interpreting K values.

calculating_k_from_concentrations.name: Calculating K from Equilibrium Concentrations
calculating_k_from_concentrations.correct: Substitute equilibrium concentrations (in mol/L) into the expression, raising each to its stoichiometric power, then calculate.

using initial concentrations.fix: Initial concentrations change as the system reaches equilibrium. Only use final values.
using initial concentrations.action: Check the question: are you given equilibrium or initial concentrations? Only equilibrium values go into K.

using moles instead of concentration.error: K requires mol/L, not just moles.
using moles instead of concentration.fix: Convert moles to concentration using c = n/V before calculating K.
using moles instead of concentration.action: If given moles and volume, divide: [X] = n/V. Then use these in K.

forgetting to apply powers.error: Each concentration must be raised to its coefficient power.
forgetting to apply powers.action: Write the K expression first, then substitute. Don't skip the powers.

adding concentrations together.error: Concentrations are multiplied within numerator and denominator, not added.
adding concentrations together.action: Review the K formula. Multiplication of concentrations, not addition.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly applying the K calculation process.
persistent.action: Steps: 1) Write expression, 2) Check concentrations are mol/L at equilibrium, 3) Substitute with correct powers, 4) Calculate.

ice_table_method.name: ICE Table Method
ice_table_method.correct: ICE tables organise information to find unknown equilibrium concentrations: Initial values, Change during reaction, Equilibrium values.

change has same sign for all species.error: Reactants decrease (negative change), products increase (positive change).
change has same sign for all species.fix: If the forward reaction proceeds, reactant change is negative, product change is positive.
change has same sign for all species.action: Mark reactants with – change, products with + change. Signs matter.

change equals equilibrium minus initial.error: That's correct, but sign conventions matter for reactants vs products.
change equals equilibrium minus initial.fix: Change = E - I. For reactants consumed, this is negative. For products formed, positive.
change equals equilibrium minus initial.action: Work through: if [A] goes from 0.5 to 0.3, change = 0.3 - 0.5 = -0.2.

initial values go directly into K.error: Only EQUILIBRIUM values are used in K.
initial values go directly into K.fix: ICE tables help find equilibrium values. Those go into K.
initial values go directly into K.action: Complete the ICE table first, then use only the E row in K.

molar ratios don't affect change.error: Change values must reflect stoichiometric ratios.
molar ratios don't affect change.fix: If A + 2B ⇌ C, and [A] changes by x, then [B] changes by 2x.
molar ratios don't affect change.action: Check stoichiometry: 1:2:1 ratio means changes are in ratio 1:2:1.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly using ICE tables to find equilibrium concentrations.
persistent.action: Practice: set up ICE tables with x for unknown change, use stoichiometry, solve for x, then calculate K.

units_of_k.name: Units of Equilibrium Constant
units_of_k.correct: K units depend on the stoichiometry. Use index laws: multiply powers for numerator, divide by denominator powers. K can be M, M⁻¹, M², or even unitless.

K always has units of M.error: K units vary depending on the reaction.
K always has units of M.fix: Add powers in numerator, subtract powers in denominator. Result determines units.
K always has units of M.action: For aA ⇌ bB: units = M^(b-a). Calculate for your specific reaction.

K is always unitless.error: K is only unitless when total powers in numerator equal denominator.
K is always unitless.fix: H₂ + I₂ ⇌ 2HI gives unitless K. N₂O₄ ⇌ 2NO₂ gives K in M.
K is always unitless.action: Count total coefficient powers on each side. Equal powers = unitless K.

units are calculated by addition.error: Index laws use multiplication, not addition, of concentration units.
units are calculated by addition.fix: M² × M = M³, not M + M + M.
units are calculated by addition.action: Review index laws: M^a × M^b = M^(a+b), M^a / M^b = M^(a-b).

units don't matter for K.error: Units are essential for correct K values.
units don't matter for K.fix: K values have different meanings with different units. Always include units.
units don't matter for K.action: Calculate K units for 3 different reactions. Compare results.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how K units are determined from stoichiometry.
persistent.action: Rule: Sum product powers minus sum reactant powers gives the M exponent. Practice with varied equations.

temperature_effect_on_k.name: Temperature Effect on K
temperature_effect_on_k.correct: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes the value of K. Other factors (concentration, pressure) shift equilibrium position but don't change K.

concentration changes K.error: Adding reactants/products shifts equilibrium but K stays constant.
concentration changes K.fix: K is defined for a given temperature. The system adjusts to restore the same K value.
concentration changes K.action: Add reactant → system shifts right → but K remains the same at that temperature.

pressure changes K.error: Pressure shifts equilibrium position but doesn't change K.
pressure changes K.fix: K is a temperature-dependent constant. Pressure affects position, not K.
pressure changes K.action: Distinguish: Le Chatelier (position shift) vs K value (only temperature).

catalysts change K.error: Catalysts speed up both forward and reverse reactions equally.
catalysts change K.fix: Catalysts don't change K. They just reach equilibrium faster.
catalysts change K.action: Catalyst: faster equilibrium, same K. No effect on position or K value.

all factors change K.error: Only temperature changes the equilibrium constant value.
all factors change K.fix: Other factors shift position. Temperature actually changes what K equals.
all factors change K.action: Key fact: K is temperature-dependent. Nothing else changes the K value.

persistent.gap: You're confusing factors that shift position with factors that change K.
persistent.action: Memorise: ONLY temperature changes K. Everything else shifts position at constant K.

temperature_direction_effect.name: Direction of Temperature Effect
temperature_direction_effect.correct: For exothermic reactions, increasing temperature decreases K. For endothermic reactions, increasing temperature increases K.

temperature always increases K.error: Direction depends on whether reaction is exothermic or endothermic.
temperature always increases K.fix: Exothermic: heat is a product. More heat → reverse favoured → K decreases.
temperature always increases K.action: Write 'heat' into equation. Exothermic: right side. Endothermic: left side.

temperature always decreases K.error: For endothermic reactions, higher temperature increases K.
temperature always decreases K.fix: Endothermic: heat is a reactant. More heat → forward favoured → K increases.
temperature always decreases K.action: Check ΔH sign: negative = exothermic, positive = endothermic. Then apply rule.

exothermic means K increases with temper.error: Exothermic reactions have K DECREASE with temperature.
exothermic means K increases with temper.fix: Adding heat favours the endothermic direction, which is reverse for exothermic reactions.
exothermic means K increases with temper.action: Think: system opposes added heat by favouring heat-absorbing direction.

ΔH sign is unrelated to K change.error: ΔH directly determines how K responds to temperature.
ΔH sign is unrelated to K change.fix: ΔH < 0 (exothermic): K decreases with T. ΔH > 0 (endothermic): K increases with T.
ΔH sign is unrelated to K change.action: Create a table: exothermic vs endothermic, effect of increasing/decreasing T on K.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the relationship between ΔH and how K responds to temperature.
persistent.action: Key rule: Increasing T shifts equilibrium toward the endothermic direction, changing K accordingly. Practice with both reaction types.

equation_form_effect.name: Effect of Equation Form on K
equation_form_effect.correct: Reversing an equation inverts K. Multiplying coefficients raises K to that power. The form of the equation determines the K value.

K is the same regardless of equation for.error: K value changes when you change how the equation is written.
K is the same regardless of equation for.fix: Reversed equation: K' = 1/K. Doubled coefficients: K' = K².
K is the same regardless of equation for.action: If K = 4 for A ⇌ B, then K = 1/4 for B ⇌ A, and K = 16 for 2A ⇌ 2B.

reversing equation doesn't affect K.fix: Products become reactants and vice versa, so the ratio inverts.
reversing equation doesn't affect K.action: If K = 100 for forward, K = 0.01 for reverse. Calculate the reciprocal.

doubling coefficients doubles K.error: Doubling coefficients SQUARES K, not doubles it.
doubling coefficients doubles K.fix: Each concentration is raised to double the power, so K' = K².
doubling coefficients doubles K.action: Example: if K = 2 for A ⇌ B, then for 2A ⇌ 2B, K' = 2² = 4.

halving coefficients halves K.error: Halving coefficients takes the square root of K.
halving coefficients halves K.fix: If you halve all coefficients, K' = √K.
halving coefficients halves K.action: If K = 16 for 2A ⇌ 2B, then K = 4 for A ⇌ B. Square root, not half.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how changing equation form affects K.
persistent.action: Rules: Reverse → reciprocal, multiply coefficients by n → K^n. Practice transformations.

homogeneous_system.name: Homogeneous Equilibrium Systems
homogeneous_system.correct: In homogeneous equilibria, all reactants and products are in the same phase (all gases or all aqueous). All species appear in the K expression.

includes solids in K expression.error: Solids have constant concentration and are excluded from K.
includes solids in K expression.fix: Homogeneous means same phase. Solids and pure liquids are excluded from K.
includes solids in K expression.action: Check: if a solid or pure liquid appears, it doesn't go in K. Only gases and aqueous.

different phases can be homogeneous.fix: If you have solid + gas, that's heterogeneous, not homogeneous.
different phases can be homogeneous.action: Homo = same. All gas or all aqueous = homogeneous.

water always appears in K.error: Pure water (liquid) is excluded; aqueous species are included.
water always appears in K.fix: H₂O(l) is constant concentration, excluded. H₂O(g) or dissolved species are included.
water always appears in K.action: Check state symbols: (l) = out, (g) or (aq) = in.

only products appear in homogeneous K.error: Both products and reactants appear in K for all equilibria.
only products appear in homogeneous K.action: Write the complete K expression including all species in the same phase.

persistent.gap: You're confusing homogeneous and heterogeneous equilibria rules.
persistent.action: Homogeneous: all same phase, all in K. Heterogeneous: solids/pure liquids excluded.

equilibrium_expression_structure.title: Equilibrium Expression Structure
equilibrium_expression_structure.content: The equilibrium expression for a reaction aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD is written as K = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b. Products always appear in the numerator and reactants in the denominator. Each concentration is raised to the power of its stoichiometric coefficient.
keyPoints: Products in numerator, reactants in denominator
Only species in the same phase appear in K for homogeneous equilibria

stoichiometric_coefficients.title: Stoichiometric Coefficients in K
stoichiometric_coefficients.content: The coefficients in a balanced equation become the powers in the equilibrium expression. A coefficient of 2 means that concentration is squared, not doubled. This mathematical relationship reflects the probability of molecular collisions.
keyPoints: Both reactants and products follow this rule
Different equation forms give different K values

k_value_meaning.title: Interpreting K Values
k_value_meaning.content: The magnitude of K indicates the position of equilibrium. K >> 1 means products are favoured (reaction proceeds almost to completion). K << 1 means reactants are favoured (reaction barely proceeds). K ≈ 1 means comparable amounts of products and reactants.

calculating_k_from_concentrations.title: Calculating K from Concentrations
calculating_k_from_concentrations.content: To calculate K, substitute equilibrium concentrations (in mol/L) into the equilibrium expression. Initial concentrations must first be converted to equilibrium concentrations using stoichiometry. Always check that units are mol/L, not moles.
keyPoints: Convert moles to mol/L using c = n/V

ice_table_method.title: ICE Table Method
ice_table_method.content: ICE (Initial, Change, Equilibrium) tables organise information for K calculations. Initial concentrations are given or calculated. Changes reflect stoichiometric ratios (negative for consumed species, positive for formed species). Equilibrium values = Initial + Change.
keyPoints: Reactant changes are negative, product changes are positive

units_of_k.title: Units of the Equilibrium Constant
units_of_k.content: K units depend on the stoichiometry of the reaction. Calculate by summing product coefficient powers minus reactant coefficient powers. This gives the exponent for M (mol/L). K can be M, M⁻¹, M², or unitless if powers cancel.
keyPoints: Units = M^(sum of product coefficients − sum of reactant coefficients)
Equal total coefficients gives unitless K
Use index laws: M^a × M^b = M^(a+b), M^a / M^b = M^(a−b)
Always include units with K values

temperature_effect_on_k.title: Temperature and K
temperature_effect_on_k.content: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes the value of K. Concentration, pressure, and catalysts shift equilibrium position but do not change K at constant temperature. Catalysts speed up both forward and reverse reactions equally.
keyPoints: Concentration/pressure shift position at constant K
Catalysts don't change K or equilibrium position

temperature_direction_effect.title: Direction of Temperature Effect
temperature_direction_effect.content: For exothermic reactions (ΔH < 0), increasing temperature decreases K. For endothermic reactions (ΔH > 0), increasing temperature increases K. Think of heat as a reactant (endothermic) or product (exothermic).
keyPoints: System shifts to oppose added heat

equation_form_effect.title: Effect of Equation Form on K
equation_form_effect.content: The form of the balanced equation affects K. Reversing an equation gives K' = 1/K. Multiplying all coefficients by n gives K' = K^n. Halving coefficients gives K' = √K.

homogeneous_system.title: Homogeneous Equilibrium Systems
homogeneous_system.content: In homogeneous equilibria, all species are in the same phase (all gases or all aqueous). All species appear in the K expression. Solids and pure liquids have constant concentration and are excluded from K expressions.
keyPoints: All gas or all aqueous species
Solids and pure liquids excluded from K
